reviews.text: It’s clear the game has already been a massive failure and so hopefully that will make them think twice about any similar releases in the future.
The actual story is told in very broad strokes, with the whole game channelling FromSoftware in terms of its narrative style...
The lack of nuance and variety is baffling given Platinum’s previous work...
There’s also the issue that Babylon’s Fall is without doubt one of the ugliest video games we’ve ever seen.
The graphics underneath are under-detailed and blandly designed...
You just enter a small sealed-off arena, kill all the enemies in it [...] and then move on to do the same again and again...
It’s basically Bayonetta without any of the depth, variety, imagination, charm, or colour.
PC usersbase was already less than a thousand on launch day...
Despite being £60 [...] the game is riddled with microtransactions...
the combat is so dull and mechanical it quickly begins to feel like a chore...
bosses take so long to whittle down
the bosses aren’t particularly hard, they just have a really big health bar
suggests that Platinum just don’t understand the Soulsborne formula
even the jump doesn’t seem to work properly, with a weird input lag...
Having four weapons in play at once is an interesting idea...
the action is more traditionally Platinum-esque
ghostly ones that float weirdly above your shoulder, which both gets in the way and looks silly
ignoring the disconnect between combining a game that’s meant to be set in ancient Mesopotamia and painting styles from Renaissance era Europe
linear corridors filled with silly-looking traps and absolutely nothing approaching an interesting idea
the game’s approach to loot and microtransactions is so dreadful though it’s hard to judge which element is the worst
the in-game store is filled with cooler looking ones you have to buy with real money
You also can’t examine or use loot during a mission, it has to be taken back to the hub area first
In truth, the whole game should’ve been dismissed in a similar manner, as there’s absolutely no hook to it
Within just a few hours of starting to play Babylon’s Fall, the idea of finishing the main campaign seems like an ordeal you’d pay good money to avoid
